statements.name: PROC HPFDIAGNOSE
statements.description: The HPFDIAGNOSE procedure provides a comprehensive set of tools for automated univariate time series model identification. Time series data can have outliers, structural changes, and calendar effects. In the past, finding a good model for time series data usually required experience and expertise in time series analysis.

arguments.name: ALPHA=
arguments.description: Specifies the confidence level size to use in computing the confidence limits in the model selection list files.

arguments.name: BACK=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of observations before the end of the data.

arguments.name: BASENAME=
arguments.description: Prefixes the model specification file name or the model selection list file name or both.

arguments.name: CRITERION=
arguments.description: Prefixes the model specification file name or the model selection list file name or both.
arguments.help: CRITERION=SSE | MSE | RMSE | UMSE | URMSE | MAXPE | MINPE | MPE | MAPE | MDAPE | GMAPE | MAPES | MDAPES | GMAPES | MINPPE | MAXPPE | MPPE | MAPPE | MDAPPE | GMAPPE | MINSPE | MAXSPE | MSPE | SMAPE | MDASPE | GMASPE | MINRE | MAXRE | MRE | MRAE | MDRAE | GMRAE | MAXERR | MINERR | ME | MAE | MASE | RSQUARE | ADJRSQ | AADJRSQ | RWRSQ | AIC | AICC | SBC | APC*option*

arguments.name: MAPES
arguments.description: mean absolute error percent of standard deviation

arguments.name: MDAPES
arguments.description: median absolute error percent of standard deviation

arguments.name: GMAPES
arguments.description: geometric mean absolute error percent of standard deviation

arguments.name: MAPPE
arguments.description: symmetric mean absolute predictive percent error

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: Specifies the name of the SAS data set that contains the time series. If the DATA= option is not specified, the most recently created SAS data set is used.

arguments.name: DELAYEVENT=
arguments.description: Specifies the delay lag for the events. If the option is not specified, the delay lag for the events is set to zero by default.

arguments.name: DELAYINPUT=
arguments.description: Specifies the delay lag for the inputs. If the option is not specified, the delay lag for the inputs is appropriately chosen by the procedure.

arguments.name: ENTRYPCT=
arguments.description: Specifies a threshold to check the percentage increment of the criterion between two candidate models. The ENTRYPCT=value should be in (0,100); the default is ENTRYPCT=0.1.

arguments.name: ERRORCONTROL=
arguments.description: [Syntax: ERRORCONTROL=( SEVERITY= ( severity-options) STAGE= ( stage-options) MAXMESSAGE=number) ] Allows finer control of message printing. The error severity level and the HPFDIAGNOSE procedure processing stages are set independently.

arguments.name: EVENTBY=
arguments.description: Specifies the name of the event data set that contains the events for specific BY groups that are created by DATA steps.

arguments.name: EXCEPTIONS=
arguments.description: Specifies the desired handling of arithmetic exceptions during the run.

arguments.name: IGNORE
arguments.description: Specifies that PROC HPFDIAGNOSE stop on an arithmetic exception.

arguments.name: CATCH
arguments.description: Specifies that PROC HPFDIAGNOSE skip the generation of diagnostic output for the variable that produces the exception in the current BY group.

arguments.name: HOLDOUT=
arguments.description: Specifies the size of the holdout sample to be used for model selection.

arguments.name: HOLDOUTPCT=
arguments.description: Specifies the size of the holdout sample as a percentage of the length of the dependent time series.

arguments.name: INEST=
arguments.description: Contains information that maps forecast variables to models or selection lists, and data set variables to model variables.

arguments.name: INEVENT=
arguments.description: Specifies the name of the event data set that contains the event definitions created by the HPFEVENTS procedure.

arguments.name: INPUTMISSINGPCT=
arguments.description: Specifies the size of the missing observation as a percentage of the length of the input time series.

arguments.name: INSELECTNAME=
arguments.description: Specifies the name of a catalog entry that serves as a model selection list.

arguments.name: MINOBS=
arguments.description: SEASON= specifies that no seasonal model is fitted to any series with fewer nonmissing observations than number (season length). The value of number must be greater than or equal to 1. The default is number = 2.

arguments.name: NODIAGNOSE
arguments.description: Specifies that the series is not diagnosed. If the INSELECTNAME= option and OUTEST= option are specified, the existing model specification files are written to the OUTEST data set.

arguments.name: NOINESTOPTS
arguments.description: Specifies that the selection lists referred to by the INEST= option are not used in the diagnosed version.

arguments.name: OUTEST=
arguments.description: Contains information that maps data set variables to model symbols and references model specification files and model selection list files.

arguments.name: OUTOUTLIER=
arguments.description: Contains information that is associated with the detected outliers.

arguments.name: OUTPROCINFO=
arguments.description: Names the output data set to contain the summary information of the processing done by PROC HPFDIAGNOSE . It is particularly useful for easy programmatic assessment of the status of the procedure’s execution via a data set instead of looking at or parsing the SAS log.

arguments.name: PREFILTER=
arguments.description: Specifies handling missing and extreme values prior to diagnostic tests.

arguments.name: MISSING
arguments.description: Smoothed values for missing data are applied for tentative order selection and missing values are used for the final diagnostics.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: Smoothed values for missing data are applied to overall diagnoses. This option is the default.

arguments.name: EXTREME
arguments.description: Extreme values set to missing for a tentative ARIMA model and extreme values are used for the final ARIMAX model diagnostics.

arguments.name: BOTH
arguments.description: This value is equivalent to both YES and EXTREME.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Suppresses the printed output. This option is the default.

arguments.name: SHORT
arguments.description: Prints the model specifications. This option also prints only the significant input variables, events, and outliers.

arguments.name: LONG
arguments.description: Prints the summary of the transform, the stationarity test, and the determination of ARMA order in addition to all of the information printed by PRINT=SHORT.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Prints the details of the stationarity test and the determination of ARMA order. This option prints the detail information about all input variables and events under consideration.

arguments.name: REPOSITORY=
arguments.description: Contains information about model specification files and model selection list files.

arguments.name: RETAINCHOOSE=
arguments.description: Specifies that the CHOOSE= option in the HPFSELECT procedure is respected when re-diagnosing series. The default is RETAINCHOOSE=YES.

arguments.name: SEASONALITY=
arguments.description: Specifies the length of the seasonal cycle. The number should be a positive integer.

arguments.name: SELECTBASE=
arguments.description: Prefixes the model selection list file name.

arguments.name: SELECTEVENT=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of events to select.

arguments.name: SELECT
arguments.description: Selects the events that satisfy the criteria (noncollinearity, smaller AIC). This option is the default.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Selects the events that satisfy the criteria (noncollinearity).

arguments.name: SELECTINPUT=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of the input variables to select.

arguments.name: SELECT
arguments.description: Selects the input variables that satisfy the criteria (noncollinearity, nonnegative delay, smaller AIC). This option is the default.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Selects the input variables that satisfy the criteria (noncollinearity, nonnegative delay).

arguments.name: SIGLEVEL=
arguments.description: Specifies the cutoff value for all diagnostic tests such as log transformation, stationarity, tentative ARMA order selection, and significance of UCM components.

arguments.name: SPECBASE=
arguments.description: Prefixes the model specification file name.

arguments.name: TESTINPUT=
arguments.description: If this option is not specified, the same differencing is applied to the input variables as is used for the variable to be forecast, and no transformation is applied to the input variables.

arguments.name: TRANSFORM
arguments.description: Specifies that the log transform testing of the input variables is applied independently of the variable to be forecast.

arguments.name: TREND
arguments.description: Specifies that the trend testing of the input variables is applied independently of the variable to be forecast.

arguments.name: BOTH
arguments.description: Specifies that the log transform and trend testing of the input variables are applied independently of the variable to be forecast.

statements.name: ADJUST
statements.description: The ADJUST statement lists the numeric variables in the DATA= data set whose accumulated values are used to adjust the dependent values. Adjustments are performed before diagnostics.
statements.help: ADJUST <ACCUMULATE=<NONE | TOTAL | AVERAGE|AVG>... > <OPERATION=<NONE | ADD | SUBTRACT>... > <SETMISSING=<MISSING | AVERAGE|AVG | MINIMUM|MIN>... > ...

arguments.name: ACCUMULATE=
arguments.description: Specifies how the data set observations are accumulated within each time period for the variables listed in the FORECAST statement.
arguments.help: ACCUMULATE=NONE | TOTAL | AVERAGE | MINIMUM | MEDIAN | MAXIMUM | N | NMISS | NOBS | FIRST | LAST | STDDEV | CSS | USS*option*

arguments.name: OPERATION=
arguments.description: Specifies how the adjustments are applied to the forecast variable.
arguments.help: OPERATION=NONE | ADD | SUBTRACT | MULTIPLY | DIVIDE | MIN | MAX*option*

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: No adjustment operation is performed. This is the default.

arguments.name: ADD
arguments.description: Variables listed in the adjustment statement are added to the dependent variable.

arguments.name: SUBTRACT
arguments.description: Variables listed in the adjustment statement are subtracted from the dependent variable.

arguments.name: MULTIPLY
arguments.description: Dependent variable is multiplied by variables listed in the adjustment statement.

arguments.name: DIVIDE
arguments.description: Dependent variable is divided by variables listed in the adjustment statement.

arguments.name: MIN
arguments.description: Dependent variable is set to the minimum of the dependent variable and all variables listed in the adjustment statement.

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: Dependent variable is set to the maximum of the dependent variable and all variables listed in the adjustment statement.

arguments.name: SETMISSING=
arguments.description: Specifies how missing values (either actual or accumulated) are assigned in the accumulated time series for variables listed in the FORECAST statement.
arguments.help: SETMISSING=MISSING | AVERAGE | MINIMUM | MEDIAN | MAXIMUM | FIRST | LAST | PREVIOUS | NEXT

arguments.name: TRIMMISS=
arguments.description: Specifies how missing values (either actual or accumulated) are trimmed from the accumulated time series for variables listed in the FORECAST statement.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: No missing value trimming is applied.

arguments.name: BOTH
arguments.description: Both beginning and ending missing value are trimmed.

arguments.name: ZEROMISS=
arguments.description: Specifies how missing values (either actual or accumulated) are trimmed from the accumulated time series for variables listed in the FORECAST statement.

arguments.name: LEFT
arguments.description: Beginning zeros are set to missing.

arguments.name: RIGHT
arguments.description: Ending zeros are set to missing.

arguments.name: BOTH
arguments.description: Both beginning and ending zeros are set to missing.

statements.name: ARIMAX
statements.description: The HPFDIAGNOSE procedure performs the intermittency test first. If the series is intermittent, an intermittent demand model is fitted to the data and the ARIMAX statement is not applicable. If the series is not intermittent, an ARIMAX model is fitted to the data.
statements.help: ARIMAX <P=(number : number) (number : number)> <PERROR=(number : number)> <Q=(number : number) (number : number)> ...

arguments.name: CRITERION=
arguments.description: Specifies the criterion for the tentative ARMA order selection. The default is CRITERION=SBC.

arguments.name: DEN=
arguments.description: Specifies the range of the denominator order of the transfer function. The default is (0:2).

arguments.name: ESTMETHOD=
arguments.description: Specifies the method for choosing the tentative ARMA orders (Choi 1992; Tsay and Tiao 1984).

arguments.name: CLS
arguments.description: Conditional least squares method. This option is the default.

arguments.name: IDENTIFYORDER=
arguments.description: Specifies the identification order when inputs and events are specified.

arguments.name: ARIMA
arguments.description: Finds an ARIMA model for the error series first and then chooses significant inputs and events. This option is the default.

arguments.name: REG
arguments.description: Finds a regression model first and then decides the AR and MA polynomial orders.

arguments.name: BOTH
arguments.description: Fits models by using the two methods and determines the better model.

arguments.name: METHOD=
arguments.description: Specifies the method for choosing the tentative ARMA orders (Choi 1992; Tsay and Tiao 1984).

arguments.name: MINIC
arguments.description: Minimum information criterion. This option is the default.

arguments.name: NUM=
arguments.description: Specifies the range of the numerator order of the transfer function. The default is (0:2).

arguments.name: OUTLIER=
arguments.description: Specifies outlier detection in an ARIMAX model (de Jong and Penzer 1998).

arguments.name: P=
arguments.description: Specifies the range of the nonseasonal and seasonal AR orders. The default is (0:5)(0:2).

arguments.name: PERROR=
arguments.description: Specifies the range of the AR order for obtaining the error series used in the MINIC method. The default is (maxp:maxp+maxq).

arguments.name: Q=
arguments.description: Specifies the range of the nonseasonal and seasonal MA orders. The default is (0:5)(0:2).

arguments.name: REFINEPARMS=
arguments.description: Specifies to refine insignificant parameters of the final model, identify the factors to refine, and identify the order of factors.

arguments.name: SIGLEVEL=
arguments.description: Specifies the significance level to use as a cutoff value to decide the AR and MA orders.

statements.name: BY
statements.description: A BY statement can be used with PROC HPFDIAGNOSE to obtain separate dummy variable definitions for groups of observations defined by the BY variables.

arguments.name: DESCENDING
arguments.description: Specifies that the observations are sorted in descending order by the variable that immediately follows the word DESCENDING in the BY statement.

arguments.name: NOTSORTED
arguments.description: Specifies that observations are not necessarily sorted in alphabetic or numeric order.

statements.name: ESM
statements.description: An ESM statement can be used to find an appropriate exponential smoothing model specification based on the model selection criterion (McKenzie 1984).

arguments.name: METHOD=
arguments.description: Specifies the identification order when inputs and events are specified.

arguments.name: BEST
arguments.description: Fits the best candidate smoothing model (SIMPLE, DOUBLE, LINEAR, DAMPTREND, SEASONAL, WINTERS, ADDWINTERS). This is the default.

arguments.name: BESTN
arguments.description: Fits the best candidate nonseasonal smoothing model (SIMPLE, DOUBLE, LINEAR, DAMPTREND).

arguments.name: BESTS
arguments.description: Fits the best candidate seasonal smoothing model (SEASONAL, WINTERS, ADDWINTERS).

statements.name: EVENT
statements.description: An ESM statement can be used to find an appropriate exponential smoothing model specification based on the model selection criterion (McKenzie 1984).

arguments.name: REQUIRED=
arguments.description: The same differencing is applied to the events as is used for the variables to be forecast. No functional transformations are applied to the events.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: Specifies that the events be included in the model as long as the model does not fail to be diagnosed.

arguments.name: MAYBE
arguments.description: Specifies that the events be included in the model as long as the parameters of events are significant.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: Specifies that the events be included in the model as long as the parameters of events are significant and the increment of the value of criterion exceeds a threshold. The default is REQUIRED=NO.

statements.name: FORECAST
statements.description: Any number of FORECAST statements can be used in the HPFDIAGNOSE procedure. The FORECAST statement lists the variables in the DATA= data set to be diagnosed. The variables are dependent or response variables that you want to forecast in the HPFENGINE procedure.
statements.help: FORECAST <ACCUMULATE=<NONE | TOTAL | AVERAGE|AVG>... > <SETMISSING=<MISSING | AVERAGE|AVG | MINIMUM|MIN>... > <TRIMMISS=<NONE | LEFT | RIGHT>... > ...

arguments.name: ACCUMULATE=
arguments.description: Specifies how the data set observations are accumulated within each time period for the variables listed in the FORECAST statement.
arguments.help: ACCUMULATE=NONE | TOTAL | AVERAGE | MINIMUM | MEDIAN | MAXIMUM | N | NMISS | NOBS | FIRST | LAST | STDDEV | CSS | USS*option*

arguments.name: SETMISSING=
arguments.description: Specifies how missing values (either actual or accumulated) are assigned in the accumulated time series for variables listed in the FORECAST statement.
arguments.help: SETMISSING=MISSING | AVERAGE | MINIMUM | MEDIAN | MAXIMUM | FIRST | LAST | PREVIOUS | NEXT

arguments.name: TRIMMISS=
arguments.description: Specifies how missing values (either actual or accumulated) are trimmed from the accumulated time series for variables listed in the FORECAST statement.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: No missing value trimming is applied.

arguments.name: BOTH
arguments.description: Both beginning and ending missing value are trimmed.

arguments.name: ZEROMISS=
arguments.description: Specifies how missing values (either actual or accumulated) are trimmed from the accumulated time series for variables listed in the FORECAST statement.

arguments.name: LEFT
arguments.description: Beginning zeros are set to missing.

arguments.name: RIGHT
arguments.description: Ending zeros are set to missing.

arguments.name: BOTH
arguments.description: Both beginning and ending zeros are set to missing.

statements.name: ID
statements.description: The ID statement names a numeric variable that identifies observations in the input and output data sets. The ID variable’s values are assumed to be SAS date, time, or datetime values. In addition, the ID statement specifies the (desired) frequency associated with the time series. The ID statement options also specify how the observations are accumulated and how the time ID values are aligned to form the time series. The information specified affects all variables specified in subsequent FORECAST statements. If the ID statement is specified, the INTERVAL= option must also be specified. If an ID statement is not specified, the observation number (with respect to the BY group) is used as the time ID.

arguments.name: ACCUMULATE=
arguments.description: Specifies how the data set observations are accumulated within each time period for the variables listed in the FORECAST statement.
arguments.help: ACCUMULATE=NONE | TOTAL | AVERAGE | MINIMUM | MEDIAN | MAXIMUM | N | NMISS | NOBS | FIRST | LAST | STDDEV | CSS | USS*option*

arguments.name: ALIGN=
arguments.description: Specifies how the data set observations are accumulated within each time period for the variables listed in the FORECAST statement.

arguments.name: END=
arguments.description: Specifies a SAS date, datetime, or time value that represents the end of the data. If the last time ID variable value is less than the END= value, the series is extended with missing values.

arguments.name: INTERVAL=
arguments.description: Specifies the frequency of the input time series.

arguments.name: SETMISSING=
arguments.description: Specifies how missing values (either actual or accumulated) are assigned in the accumulated time series for variables listed in the FORECAST statement.
arguments.help: SETMISSING=MISSING | AVERAGE | MINIMUM | MEDIAN | MAXIMUM | FIRST | LAST | PREVIOUS | NEXT

arguments.name: START=
arguments.description: Specifies a SAS date, datetime, or time value that represents the beginning of the data.

arguments.name: TRIMMISS=
arguments.description: Specifies how missing values (either actual or accumulated) are trimmed from the accumulated time series for variables listed in the FORECAST statement.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: No missing value trimming is applied.

arguments.name: BOTH
arguments.description: Both beginning and ending missing value are trimmed.

arguments.name: ZEROMISS=
arguments.description: Specifies how missing values (either actual or accumulated) are trimmed from the accumulated time series for variables listed in the FORECAST statement.

arguments.name: LEFT
arguments.description: Beginning zeros are set to missing.

arguments.name: RIGHT
arguments.description: Ending zeros are set to missing.

arguments.name: BOTH
arguments.description: Both beginning and ending zeros are set to missing.

statements.name: IDM
statements.description: An IDM statement is used to control the intermittency test. The HPFDIAGNOSE procedure performs the intermittency test first.

arguments.name: BASE=
arguments.description: Specifies how missing values (either actual or accumulated) are trimmed from the accumulated time series for variables listed in the FORECAST statement.

arguments.name: AUTO
arguments.description: The time series properties are used to automatically adjust the time series.

arguments.name: INTERMITTENT
arguments.description: Specifies a number greater than one that is used to determine whether or not a time series is intermittent.

statements.name: INPUT
statements.description: Any number of INPUT statements can be used in the HPFDIAGNOSE procedure. The INPUT statement lists the variables in the DATA= data set to be diagnosed as regressors. The variables are independent or predictor variables to be used to forecast dependent or response variables.
statements.help: INPUT <ACCUMULATE=<NONE | TOTAL | AVERAGE|AVG>... > <REQUIRED=<YES | MAYBE | NO>> <SETMISSING=<MISSING | AVERAGE|AVG | MINIMUM|MIN>... > ...

arguments.name: ACCUMULATE=
arguments.description: Specifies how the data set observations are accumulated within each time period for the variables listed in the FORECAST statement.
arguments.help: ACCUMULATE=NONE | TOTAL | AVERAGE | MINIMUM | MEDIAN | MAXIMUM | N | NMISS | NOBS | FIRST | LAST | STDDEV | CSS | USS*option*

arguments.name: REQUIRED=
arguments.description: Either the POSITIVE or NEGATIVE option with parentheses can follow the REQUIRED= option. For examples REQUIRED=YES(POSITIVE) and REQUIRED=MAYBE(NEGATIVE). When the REQUIRED=YES(POSITIVE) option is specified, if its coefficient is negative, then the input variable drops out from the model.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: Specifies that the input variables be included in the model as long as the model does not fail to be diagnosed.

arguments.name: MAYBE
arguments.description: Specifies that the input variables be included in the model as long as their parameters are significant.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: Specifies that the input variables be included in the model as long as their parameters are significant and the increment of the value of criterion exceeds a threshold.

arguments.name: SETMISSING=
arguments.description: Specifies how missing values (either actual or accumulated) are assigned in the accumulated time series for variables listed in the FORECAST statement.
arguments.help: SETMISSING=MISSING | AVERAGE | MINIMUM | MEDIAN | MAXIMUM | FIRST | LAST | PREVIOUS | NEXT

arguments.name: TRIMMISS=
arguments.description: Specifies how missing values (either actual or accumulated) are trimmed from the accumulated time series for variables listed in the FORECAST statement.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: No missing value trimming is applied.

arguments.name: BOTH
arguments.description: Both beginning and ending missing value are trimmed.

arguments.name: ZEROMISS=
arguments.description: Specifies how missing values (either actual or accumulated) are trimmed from the accumulated time series for variables listed in the FORECAST statement.

arguments.name: LEFT
arguments.description: Beginning zeros are set to missing.

arguments.name: RIGHT
arguments.description: Ending zeros are set to missing.

arguments.name: BOTH
arguments.description: Both beginning and ending zeros are set to missing.

statements.name: TRANSFORM
statements.description: A TRANSFORM statement can be used to specify the functional transformation of the series.

arguments.name: P=
arguments.description: Specifies the autoregressive order for the log transform test.

arguments.name: SIGLEVEL=
arguments.description: Specifies the significance level to use as a cutoff value to decide whether or not the series requires a log transformation.

arguments.name: TRANSOPT=
arguments.description: Specifies whether mean or median forecasts are produced. If no transformation is applied to the series, then the mean and median forecasts are identical.

arguments.name: MEAN
arguments.description: The inverse transform produces mean forecasts. This is the default.

arguments.name: MEDIAN
arguments.description: The inverse transform produces median forecasts.

arguments.name: TYPE=
arguments.description: Specifies the type of functional transformation.
arguments.help: TYPE=AUTO | LOG | NONE | SQRT | LOGISTIC | BOXCOX

arguments.name: AUTO
arguments.description: Automatically choose between NONE and LOG based on model selection criteria. If the TRANSFORM statement is specified but the TYPE= option is not specified, then TYPE=AUTO is the default.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: No transformation is applied. If the TRANSFORM statement is not specified, TYPE=NONE is the default.

arguments.name: BOXCOX
arguments.description: Box-Cox transformation with a parameter value where the value is between –5 and 5. The default is BOXCOX(1).

statements.name: TREND
statements.description: A TREND statement can be used to test whether the dependent series requires simple or seasonal differencing, or both. The augmented Dickey-Fuller test (Dickey and Fuller 1979) is used for the simple unit root test.

arguments.name: AUTO
arguments.description: Tests for simple differencing. This option is the default.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Specifies that no simple differencing be used.

arguments.name: P=
arguments.description: Specifies the autoregressive order for the augmented unit root tests and a seasonality test.

arguments.name: SDIFF=
arguments.description: Specifies seasonal differencing to be used.

arguments.name: AUTO
arguments.description: Tests for seasonal differencing. This option is the default.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Specifies that no seasonal differencing be used.

arguments.name: SIGLEVEL=
arguments.description: Specifies the significance level to use as a cutoff value to decide whether or not the series needs differencing.

statements.name: UCM
statements.description: A UCM statement can be used to find an appropriate unobserved component model specification (Harvey 1989, 2001; Durbin and Koopman 2001).
statements.help: UCM <COMPONENT=<ALL | AUTOREG | CYCLE>... > <REFINEPARMS= ( SIGLEVEL= | FACTOR=(ALL | EVENT | INPUT) | FIRST=EVENT | INPUT)> <SIGLEVEL=value> ...

arguments.name: COMPONENT=
arguments.help: COMPONENT=ALL | AUTOREG | CYCLE | DEPLAG | IRREGULAR | LEVEL | SEASON | SLOPE

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Tests which components and/or variances are significant in the model. This option is the default.

arguments.name: AUTOREG
arguments.description: Tests if an autoregreesive component is significant in the model.

arguments.name: CYCLE
arguments.description: Tests if two cycle components are significant in the model.

arguments.name: DEPLAG
arguments.description: Tests if a dependent lag component is significant in the model.

arguments.name: IRREGULAR
arguments.description: Tests if an irregular component is significant in the model.

arguments.name: LEVEL
arguments.description: Tests if a level component is significant in the model.

arguments.name: SEASON
arguments.description: Tests if a season component is significant in the model.

arguments.name: SLOPE
arguments.description: Tests if a slope component is significant in the model.

arguments.name: REFINEPARMS=
arguments.description: Specifies to refine insignificant parameters of the final model, identify the factors to refine, and identify the order of factors.

arguments.name: SIGLEVEL=
arguments.description: Specifies the significance level to use as a cutoff value to decide which component and/or variances are significant.
